2. Part 2: Local Pilot Usage¶

One of the most important feature of Sinon is ...

If you are somewhat familiar with Python and the principles of distributed computing, the Hands-On code example is probably all you want to know. The code is relatively simple and pretty self-explanatory. If you have questions about the code or if you want to know in detail what’s going on, read the Details and Discussion section further below.

2.1. Hands-On: Local Pilot Submission¶

Before we discuss the individual API calls in more detail, let’s get down and dirty and run our first example: creating and running a Sinon pilot on your local machine.

Create a new file sinon_example_local.py and paste the following code:

2.1.1. Run the Code¶

Save the file and execute it (make sure your virtualenv is activated):

python sinon_example_local.py

The output should look something like this:

Job ID    : [fork://localhost]-[None]
Job State : sinon.job.Job.New

...starting job...

Job ID    : [fork://localhost]-[644240]
Job State : sinon.job.Job.Pending

...waiting for job...

Job State : sinon.job.Job.Done
Exitcode  : None

2.1.2. Check the Output¶

Once the job has completed, you will find a file mysinonjob.stdout in your current working directory. It should contain the line:

Hello from Sinon

2.1.3. A Quick Note on Logging and Debugging¶

Since working with distributed systems is inherently complex and much of the complexity is hidden within Sinon, it is necessary to do a lot of internal logging. By default, logging output is disabled, but if something goes wrong or if you’re just curious, you can enable the logging output by setting the environment variable SINON_VERBOSE to a value between 1 (print only critical messages) and 5 (print all messages). Give it a try with the above example:

SINON_VERBOSE=5 python sinon_example_local.py

2.2. Discussion¶

Now that we have successfully run our first job with sinon-python, we will discuss some of the the building blocks and details of the code.

The job submission and management capabilities of sinon-python are packaged in the `sinon.job module (API Doc). Three classes are defined in this module:

  • The job.Service class provides a handle to the resource manager, like for example a remote PBS cluster.
  • The job.Description class is used to describe the executable, arguments, environment and requirements (e.g., number of cores, etc) of a new job.
  • The job.Job class is a handle to a job associated with a job.Service. It is used to control (start, stop) the job and query its status (e.g., Running, Finished, etc).

In order to use the Sinon Job API, we first need to import the sinon-python module:

import sinon

Next, we create a job.Service object that represents the compute resource you want to use (see figure above). The job service takes a single URL as parameter. The URL is a way to tell sinon-python what type of resource or middleware you want to use and where it is. The URL parameter is passed to sinon-python’s plug- in selector and based on the URL scheme, a plug-in is selected. In this case the Local job plug-in is selected for fork://. URL scheme - Plug-in mapping is described in chapter_adaptors.

js = sinon.job.Service("fork://localhost")

To define a new job, a job.Description object needs to be created that contains information about the executable we want to run, its arguments, the environment that needs to be set and some other optional job requirements:

jd = sinon.job.Description()

# environment, executable & arguments
jd.environment = {'MYOUTPUT':'"Hello from Sinon"'}
jd.executable  = '/bin/echo'
jd.arguments   = ['$MYOUTPUT']

# output options
jd.output = "mysinonjob.stdout"
jd.error  = "mysinonjob.stderr"

Once the job.Service has been created and the job has been defined via the job.Description object, we can create a new instance of the job via the create_job method of the job.Service and use the resulting object to control (start, stop) and monitor the job:

myjob = js.create_job(jd) # create a new job instance
myjob.run() # start the job instance
print "Initial Job ID    : %s" % (myjob.jobid)
print "Initial Job State : %s" % (myjob.get_state())
myjob.wait() # Wait for the job to reach either 'Done' or 'Failed' state
print "Final Job ID    : %s" % (myjob.jobid)
print "Final Job State : %s" % (myjob.get_state())
